body: Would moving memcached and local to extensions make sense?
Or maybe just memcached
A "reference implementation" with no external dependencies is a good thing to keep in core druid
Having quality extensions helps serve as examples and templates for new developers.

Are you envisioning a path to deprecating¬†and eventually removing `local` in that case? I was thinking a process like (1) move caffeine to core, (2) deprecate local, (3) remove local, (4) now caffeine is the only remaining local mode cache.

If caffeine stays an extension that at steps (3) and (4) we won't have any cache impl in core.

I was thinking:

1. Make things that are extension point AND require external dependencies be an extension
2. Move memcached to an extension
3. Make "local" the reference implementation inside of Druid and memcached/caffeine the reference extensions in extensions-core.
4. Since the hybrid cache doesn't require external dependencies, I'm not quite sure where it would fall here.

I'm not convinced this is the right way to go, this is just the first time we've had an extension that is hands down superior to the things that have been packaged in druid before. So spending some time figuring out what should be a core-extension vs what should be packaged in druid default makes some sense.

Core extensions are already packaged in every release, and cache is disabled by default, so since people have to choose the cache impl anyways and modify configs, I don't think it is undue burden.
so by "make default" if this means "use in all the examples and highly recommend it" then that can (and should) be done in either scenario.

I don't see a purpose of keeping `local` around if `caffeine` is just straight up better. `caffeine` can still serve as a reference implementation, even though it delegates to another library it still does a good job of demonstrating how to write a Druid cache implementation.
@pjain1 are you planning on working on a patch for this?
Yes..I am working on this. I will try to send a PR by end of this week.
Great, thanks. Let me know if you want to discuss anything, otherwise looking forward to it!

Retaining `local` becomes the easiest (preferred) solution for users looking to quickly solve a performance problem. You might later want to enable it by default if you want a good out-of-the-box experience. I'd argue for removal of `local` because there seems to be no benefit, there is more code to maintain, and it might confuse users.

I have no opinion on whether it should be replaced by Caffeine going into core or all caches becoming extensions. I'd only advise to favor towards a new user's experience where they will make minimal changes to your distribution's configuration.
@b-slim sorry to let this drop for so long, I am taking another look now.

:+1: after travis

I made all changes. I didn't really make a new test for long and float but instead added a long and float value to the current tests.

Oh, it's in the context! I somehow thought it was option directly on the query. Works fine, thanks.
Not as much difference in performance as I kinda expected, I think I'm gonna do some more profiling anyway.
Thanks @erikdubbelboer, will take another look today.

It reduces 10%~20% time in huge group by query in my production environment. For `huge`, I mean it returns lots of rows from lots of historicals (36000*32 rows, 2 dimensions in each row, in my environment), thus the json is huge. Currently, broker deserializes json in single thread, so the deserialization on broker becomes bottleneck. @KenjiTakahashi
10%~20% sounds about right. In #3740 we benchmarked a roughly 30% improvement for removing timestamps completely (set to null) from the historical -> broker communication when they aren't necessary.

Should I serialize and deserialize timeZone in this PR? It may gain less improvement. My case uses PeriodGranularity with +08:00 timezone, groupby and timeseries query can handle long timestamp correctly by granularity.truncate(), so there is no need to serialize and deserialize timeZone for these two queries. @gianm

@kaijianding hmm, maybe time zone isn't necessary then, if the granularity object on the broker "knows" the proper time zone and can reapply it. It sounds like that's what you're saying, in which case just using the millis should be fine.

Really I'm just pushing to do something we can have on all the time, automatically, rather than something that requires users to set a special context flag. Then a lot more users will get the benefit, since most users just stick with defaults for things like this.
Ok. Then I will make serializeDateTimeAsLongInner=true as default, and serialize and deserialize timeZone @gianm
@leventov any other comments?

Hi tallongsun!
I see in your finalizeComputation method you build a list of individual values scaled by the factor of 1/theta. I don't think this makes sense. Individual values are exact, but they are present only for those keys, which ended up being retained in the sketch (uniform random sample of keys). Could you explain your use case please?

@himanshug please don't rebase PR, merge master into the PRed branch instead. It simplifies review and preserves older review comments in the code, if the part of code is not changed by merge/later commits, addressing PR review. With rebase and force push, comments are vanished anyway.

There didn't seem to be a good way to handle the case Gian mentioned without some significant changes and it's a fairly edgy case that I think currently would only affect this exact scenario (a paginated select query with a union datasource where one datasource is the prefix of the second datasource and the second half of the string is _{DateTime}. I think it makes sense to exclude that case from here (especially since it was existing) and deal with it later if necessary. I added a comment to the method regarding this case. If you think it's worth filing an issue for, let me know and we can address it later if that seems okay.

Hi AlexanderSaydakov!
If value is present for count, this method can estimate the total count. If value is present for sum and the data distribution is uniformly, this method can also estimate the total sum. If value is present for max/min, this make no sense. 
Actually In my use case, shouldFinalize field in the query json is set to false, so I will get the sketch object. And then, do union/intersection operation and compute according to business logic in my app program. My finalizeComputation method is just for test now, I will modify it with a more commonly may.
Also a good timeseries compression algorithm is described here: http://www.vldb.org/pvldb/vol8/p1816-teller.pdf (Gorilla paper)
Update: Still working on it, will require few more days.

I've seen about 20% as well. Back when we were profiling the `select` query, one of things that were coming up quite often were Joda stuff, so I kinda expected a bit more (like ~50% maybe?).

There are multiple problems with JSON as efficient serialization for larger sets of data, maybe at some point we'd be able to introduce something better for this purpose?

Option 2 sounds better.
I currently face the same problem. I have an extension which requires `QuerySegmentWalker`, but overlord doesn't have one and overlord failed to start, I have to override extension list in runtime.properties to fix it.

Thanks for looking at this!

We are currently talking to historical(s) directly, but performance of `scan` query seems pretty much linear, so it's OK. We usually don't actually use `limit`, but with `int`, the number of events returned if `limit` is not set was of course `2^31-1`, which is sometimes not enough.

We have a system where users can construct their own queries with a graphical designer. We are then transforming them to our internal "language" and later optimise whatever we can with Druid side aggregations. But there are always things that will require pulling raw data. And some users use our system for "report like" queries, which touch many events, but are only run once a day, or even week, etc.
We are kinda stretching the limits of Druid here, but introducing another huge dependency (e.g. Hadoop) bears too much maintenance cost for this, at least for now.
Got it, thx for the explaination.

Yeah, it makes sense to explore options other than JSON. Druid uses JSON since all the original query types (timeBoundary, timeseries, topN, search) return relatively small result sets and so serde overhead of results doesn't matter much. But for groupBy, select, and scan, it does matter.
@leventov any more comments?
FYI: The long query I've mentioned completed successfully, returning 4800000000 events, as expected.

üëç

Another problem is that CONTRIBUTING.md suggests to do rebases, instead of merging master into feature branch. Rebases are very inconvenient for reviewing, because reviewer cannot separately look at changes that he hasn't yet reviewed, and also older comments to the code are lost.

Before Github used to display full diffs of merge commits so it was also inconvenient for reviewing. But now Github always displays diff between the feature branch and the current master, so this problem is gone.

I think the changes address that concern, it now says:

> Avoid rebasing and force pushes after submitting a pull request, since these make it difficult for reviewers to see what you've changed in response to their reviews.
Is it worth documenting? Seems like it to me.
Added benchmark results to my second comment in this PR's thread
Except for collections from fastutils, because they don't have specialized forms of those methods yet. See https://github.com/vigna/fastutil/issues/57

> you mean here: https://github.com/DataSketches/memory?

Yes.

It was recommended by both @cheddar and @niketh that the byte-ordering functionality is not essential, and that it was more important to get this package out, so that folks can start working with it.  I have no plans to implement byte-ordering.  

@niketh already has submitted a PR based on the original memory API and has a real good understanding of the implementation issues, and will be the one using this new API to resubmit a new PR based on it.  Certainly if he runs into issues with the API we will make adjustments.

> It was recommended by both @cheddar and @niketh that the byte-ordering functionality is not essential, and that it was more important to get this package out, so that folks can start working with it. I have no plans to implement byte-ordering.

This is one of the things that actual attempt of refactoring of Druid should verify. So yes, we can try to start refactoring without byteOrdering functionality and see if it works well.

Maybe, we should add `kryo-extension` for better performance about the speed of serializer and the ratio of compression.

Patch in #4094.

That looks like we need to set the "ignore unrecognized property" flag on whatever object mapper Tranquility is using, so probably a Tranquility bug rather than Druid bug.

What's the nature of the incompatibility exactly? Do you get that error when you run latest Tranquility against a Druid 0.10.0-rc1 cluster?
@gianm We are using 0.5.0 version tranquility against a Druid latest (master branch - commit 6febcd9)
üëç

@gianm regarding your questions about the contract.  I agree that what you did in groupBy v2 is totally valid and 100%, totally according to contract.  

The basic contract is really simply described by the function signatures and that is "you get a ByteBuffer and a position, use the position on the ByteBuffer and your bytes will be there".  There is then the other one of "an area of memory is always initialized before being aggregated into", that one isn't called out in the docs as well.
üëç

@leventov @akashdw I'm sorry to see such an argument between two people that clearly have strong feelings about Druid!

My vote is to defer to @akashdw's choice for 0.10.0 assuming it is acceptable to committers that are using DataSketches in production (like @himanshug, @cheddar). But I would also like to open an issue¬†for the future to clarify the BufferAggregator contract ‚Äî it sounds like it's pretty confusing what it allows and doesn't allow ‚Äî¬†and then use that clarified contract to optimize SketchBufferAggregator more after 0.10.0.

> @akashdw @himanshug this is BDUF. Possible redesign of BufferGrouper which won't include "rehash" will make relocate() obsolete as well, so rework of SketchBufferAggregator will be needed anyway.

I don't think it's BDUF, since `Query` and `BufferAggregator` are both valid extension points for Druid extensions, and we can't assume we can control all possible implementations. We need the interfaces to be clear about what is allowed and disallowed, and we shouldn't write code that violates them, or else users' site specific custom Queries and Aggregators might not work properly.

Even future code written as part of Druid might not work properly, after we all put this behind us and forget that SketchBufferAggregator doesn't quite follow the contract 100%. This is actually how we got into this situation in the first place! When I wrote groupBy v2, I used BufferAggregator interface in a way that other queries hadn't done before, which I thought satisfied the contract, but broke SketchBufferAggregator. Arguably, the old version of SketchBufferAggregator didn't follow the contract, but it was "OK" until the change to groupBy.

So, I think the maps are useful and it's valid choice to be a little "flexible" until the BufferAggregator interface is clarified.
@gianm addressed comments, thanks for review

@niketh, I tried locally and confirmed this is still a bug with the latest tranquility. It's fixed by updating Tranquility's Curator. After doing that, tranquility works against both Druid 0.10.0 and 0.9.2. Probably other versions too!

I'll send a Tranquility PR in a bit.
